asthma.description: This document outlines the Asthma Pathway in India, covering its high burden, diagnosis challenges (spirometry access, underdiagnosis), stepwise pharmacological management for adults and children, exacerbation protocols, and key interventions to avoid.

L3.content: - • GBD study estimates 34.3 million patients with asthma in India, accounting for 13.09%

L4.content: - of the total asthma burden

L5.content: - • India has 3x higher asthma mortality and 2x higher asthma morbidity compared to global

L7.content: - • Asthma is underdiagnosed and undertreated in India

L9.content: - • GINA

L10.content: Global Initiative for Asthma. Global Strategy for Asthma Management and

L11.content: - Prevention, 2023. Updated May 2023. Available from: www.ginasthma.org

L13.content: - • Indian Guidelines (2015)

L14.content: - • UK guidelines (BTS, NICE)

L15.content: - • US NIH guidelines

L18.content: - • International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (The Union)

L23.content: Diagnosis of asthma requires evidence of variable expiratory airflow obstruction

L24.content: The gold standard approach requires access to spirometry.

L25.content: - • Treatment – ensuring appropriate, evidence-based stepwise treatment

L26.content: - • Education – including appropriate use of inhalers, literacy?

L27.content: - • Non-pharmacological management

L28.content: - • Key barriers

L30.content: Financial – inhalers remain expensive/unaffordable in LMICs

L31.content: - • Currently do not address:

L34.content: - • Intermittent dyspnoea, cough, wheeze, chest tightness

L35.content: - • Diagnosis requires symptoms + variable expiratory airflow obstruction

L36.content: - • Spirometry criteria:

L38.content: AND reversibility (improvement in FEV1/FVC after 2-4 puffs of SABA)

L39.content: - ▪ daily/ Cefotaxime1 g IV every six hours*

L40.content: - ▪ Increase of ≥12 percent and 200 mL in FEV1

L41.content: Alternatively: 20% improvement in peak expiratory flow 15 minutes after

L42.content: - bronchodilation (for LMICs)

L43.content: - • In high-income settings, asthma is often overdiagnosed, or diagnosed without diagnostic

L45.content: Differential Diagnosis (based on “cough” per UpToDate )

L46.content: - • chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

L47.content: - • gastroesophageal reflux disease

L49.content: - • rhinitis or rhinosinus

L50.content: - • post-viral tussive syndrome

L51.content: - • eosinophilic bronchitis

L52.content: - • cough induced by angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors

L53.content: - • infection with Bordetella pertussis

L55.content: - • Smoking cessation

L56.content: - • Avoid triggers

L58.content: - • Low dose ICS/rapid onset LABA (Track 1) OR

L59.content: - • SABA + ICS whenever SABA used (Track 2)

L60.content: Step 2: Symptoms or need for inhaler ≥ 2 times/week

L61.content: - • Low dose ICS-formoterol as needed (Track 1) OR

L62.content: - • Low dose ICS daily AND SABA (Track 2)

L63.content: Step 3: symptoms on most days, nocturnal awakening due to asthma ≥ once/month, risk factors

L65.content: - • Low dose ICS-formoterol for maintenance and reliever (MART; Track 1) OR

L66.content: - • Low dose ICS-LABA AND SABA (Track 2)

L67.content: Step 4: severe uncontrolled asthma with ≥ of: daytime symptoms ≥ 2 times/week, nocturnal

L68.content: awakening due to asthma, reliever needed > 2 times/week, activity limitation

L69.content: - • Low dose ICS-formoterol for maintenance and reliever (MART; Track 1) OR

L70.content: - • Low dose ICS-LABA AND SABA (Track 2)

L71.content: Step 5: Consider high dose ICS-LABA and Add-on LAMA

L73.content: Step 1: Symptoms less than twice a month and no risk factors for exacerbation

L74.content: - • As needed SABA

L75.content: Step 2: Symptoms or need for reliever more than twice a month but less than daily

L76.content: - • Low dose ICS with as-needed SABA

L77.content: Step 3: Symptoms most days, nocturnal awakenings due to asthma, especially in the context of

L79.content: - • Low dose ICS-LABA with as needed SABA OR

L80.content: - • Medium dose ICS with as needed SABA

L81.content: Step 4: As for Step 3, but with poor lung function

L82.content: - • Medium dose ICS-LABA AND referral to specialist

L85.content: - • Day to day adjustments

L86.content: Reliever inhaler can be adjusted as needed (i.e. used more)

L87.content: - • Short term adjustments: increase in ICS dose for 1-2 weeks may be necessary (e.g. if

L88.content: - • viral illness, or allergen/pollution exposure)

L90.content: - • Continue with same treatment and once good asthma control has been achieved and

L91.content: - maintained for 2–3 months, consider stepping down gradually to find the patient’s lowest

L92.content: - treatment that controls both symptoms and exacerbations.

L94.content: - • Inhaler technique!!

L95.content: - • Confirm/reconsider diagnosis

L96.content: - • Assess risk factors and comorbidities

L97.content: - • Consider stepping up treatment

L98.content: Management of exacerbations- location of management based on extent of exacerbation.

L100.content: - • All patients should be provided an asthma action plan

L101.content: - • Home therapy of exacerbations depends on whether we are doing Step 1 or Step 2

L102.content: - • Increase reliever for acute exacerbation

L103.content: If usual reliever is ICS-LABA, increase frequency not exceeding maximum daily

L104.content: - dosage of inhaler

L105.content: If usual reliever is SABA, then increase frequency

L106.content: - • Increase preventer to prevent future exacerbations

L107.content: If usual preventer is ICS-formoterol, continue maintenance ICS-formoterol AND

L108.content: - increase reliever ICS-formoterol as required

L109.content: If usual preventer is ICS with SABA as reliever, quadruple ICS dose

L110.content: - • Above changes should be continued for 1-2 weeks

L111.content: - • If peak flow is < 60% of previous best peak flow, OR if not improving after 48 hours

L116.content: - • Assess clinical stability

L117.content: If severe: If unable to talk in full sentences, respiratory rate > 30, accessory

L118.content: - muscle use, HR > 120, SpO2 on air < 90%, peak flow < 50%

L119.content: - ▪ Transfer to higher center of care

L120.content: - ▪ In the interim, give SABA, ipratropium bromide, O2, systemic

L122.content: If mild or moderate: talks in phrases, prefers sitting to lying down, not agitated,

L123.content: - respiratory rate increased from baseline, accessory muscles not used, pulse 100-

L124.content: - 120 beats per minute, O2 saturation on air 90-95%, peak flow >50% predicted or

L126.content: - ▪ Treat at clinic

L127.content: - ▪ Salbutamol 4-10 puffs via spacer, every 20 minutes for 1 hour

L128.content: - ▪ Prednisolone 40-50mg (adults), children 1-2mg/kg max 40mg

L129.content: - ▪ O2 therapy if available: target SpO2 93-95% (children 94-98%)

L130.content: - ▪ Reassess at 1 hour

L131.content: - • If worsening, requires transfer to higher center of care

L132.content: - • If improving, discharge, signs of improvement below

L133.content: - o Improving symptoms, no SABA requirement

L134.content: - o Peak flow 60-80% of predicted or personal best

L135.content: - o SpO2 > 94% on room air

L136.content: - o Safe discharge destination

L137.content: - o Ensure has home action plan

L138.content: - ▪︎ Prednisolone – to be continued for 5-7 days

L140.content: - ▪︎ Follow up within 2-7 days (adults), 1-2 days

L142.content: - ▪︎ continue the rescue inhaler as needed. rescue inhaler

L143.content: - may be SABA, low dose ICS-LABA, or ICS-SABA

L144.content: - ▪︎ up titrate maintenance inhaler- ICS-LABA – to be

L145.content: - continued or uptitrated

L147.content: - • Both are obstructive conditions with overlapping diagnostic criteria

L148.content: - • Some patients may have features of both conditions

L149.content: Particularly if long standing asthma and risk factors for COPD (e.g. smoking)

L150.content: - • For patients with features of both asthma and COPD, treat as asthma with ICS

L151.content: First line therapy for COPD (i.e. LAMA or LABA without ICS) is not appropriate

L152.content: - for patients with features of asthma (see CSA COPD pathway)

L154.content: - • Risk factor modification/non-pharmacological measures?

L155.content: - • Other than avoiding smoke/pollution, this is tricky

L157.content: - • Do not use oral steroids as a first line therapy for asthma

L158.content: “It is not acceptable in 2022 to manage asthma with SABAs and oral

L159.content: - corticosteroids instead of preventive ICS-containing treatments” – GINA

L160.content: - • Avoid SABA monotherapy, even in cases of mild asthma

L161.content: Associated with increased rates of asthma-related death, and urgent asthma-

L162.content: - related healthcare

L163.content: - • Do not treat asthma exacerbations with corticosteroid therapy

L164.content: - • Do not treat asthma with methylxanthines (e.g. theophylline)

fever.description: This pathway addresses adult acute fever in India's resource-limited settings. It covers diagnosis challenges, common causes, severity assessment, and empiric antimicrobial treatments for various infections like malaria, typhoid, and dengue.

L3.content: - • Symptoms of fever (2 consecutive temperature elevations > 38.3°C (100.9 °F) or a single

L4.content: - oral temperature > 38.3°C (100.9°F) in neutropenic persons without evidence of an

L5.content: - environmental cause OR a temperature elevation > 38°C for > 1 hour) for a period of 3-

L7.content: - • No clear localizable symptoms to suggest immediate diagnosis

L9.content: - Infectious Diseases are the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in India.

L10.content: - Undifferentiated acute febrile syndromes vary by season, location and may present a challenge to

L11.content: - the general practitioner. They are overwhelmingly caused by infectious

L12.content: - Fever episodes in rural tropical areas may be 4 per person per year in rural and 0.5 per person per

L14.content: - Early presentation may be nonspecific and overlapping for many infections and may make

L15.content: - distinguishing self-limited illness from more severe illness difficult.

L16.content: - Early recognition and appropriate specific antimicrobial therapy may lead to decreased morbidity

L17.content: - and mortality for some infections. However indiscriminate empiric antibiotic therapy should be

L18.content: - avoided in conditions where there may be limited role to avoid emergence of antimicrobial

L23.content: - • Patients in many parts of India do not need to see a doctor to obtain antibiotics for fever

L24.content: - • Access to reliable clinical bacteriology laboratory for identification and antimicrobial

L25.content: - susceptibility testing on specimens (blood cultures, urine cultures) is an important part of

L26.content: - the clinical evaluation and treatment in the AUFI pathway but may be limited in low

L27.content: - resource location or have an unacceptable turnaround time within the clinical context of

L28.content: - such patient encounters. A follow up encounter may be necessary to make therapy

L29.content: - changes based on antimicrobial susceptibility results and may not be feasible. (PMID:

L31.content: - • Burden of multidrug resistant organisms as a cause of community onset acute febrile

L32.content: - illness is high and may lead to higher mortality unless antibiotic therapy is guided by

L33.content: - antimicrobial susceptibility testing. (PMID 28329303; 35065702)

L34.content: - • Patients and clinicians may be reluctant to undergo invasive procedures including blood

L35.content: - sampling due to perceptions that tests may be timely or expensive or irrelevant. The post analytical

L36.content: - laboratory clinician interaction may not be timely or in person

L37.content: - • Prior antibiotic therapy may render a blood culture sample sterile and decrease yield.

L38.content: - • Cross reactivity as well as background positivity from prior infections in endemic areas

L39.content: - are limitations of serologic tests used to diagnose some infections (Dengue, Leptospirosis

L40.content: - and Chikungunya) and convalescent testing to confirm diagnosis may not be feasible.

L41.content: - Hence clinical diagnosis should guide therapy in cases where test results are discordant to

L43.content: - • In endemic areas, background seroprevalence may be high for antibody-based tests

L44.content: - (example >50% Leptospira Ab in Andamans, slum dwellers or sewer workers)

L45.content: - • Sensitivity of serologic tests for Dengue, Leptospirosis and Scrub typhus are limiting, but

L46.content: - remember the clinical suspicion may increase predictive value of a positive test.

L47.content: - • The Widal test for typhoid is widely used but is not recommended due to low sensitivity

L48.content: - and specificity. However, if it is performed elsewhere, or is the only test available, it

L49.content: - should be used in clinical decision making only for its negative predictive value which is

L50.content: - around 95% even in high prevalence settings. (PMID 24995178)

L51.content: - • Patients may not present to CSA partner sites with mild-moderate symptoms (can present

L52.content: - directly to pharmacy for antibiotics)

L54.content: - • What to test/when to test

L55.content: - • How to treat/what to treat with

L58.content: - • National Centre for Disease Control in India (NCDC): National Treatment Guidelines for

L59.content: - Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases

L60.content: - • WHO report on fever management in peripheral healthcare settings (2013)

L61.content: - • WHO: Good clinical diagnostic practice: a guide for clinicians in developing countries to

L62.content: - the clinical diagnosis of disease and to making proper use of clinical diagnostic services.

L64.content: - • National Vector Borne Disease Control Program guidelines (2013)

L67.content: - • Early assessment of severity and SIRS response

L69.content: - • Define clinical syndrome and identify clinical cues. This is guided by history and

L70.content: - physical exam. A good practice is to conduct a system-based review of symptoms

L71.content: - (negative history). Clinical history would include assessment for

L73.content: ear pain, sinus pain, dental pain,

L75.content: cough, sputum, shortness of breath, wheezing

L79.content: joint pain, swelling or bone pain

L81.content: - Physical examination would assess for

L82.content: rapid pulse, rapid respiratory rate (exception: slow pulse in typhoid fever)

L85.content: red throat, pus on tonsils, red bulging eardrums,

L87.content: respiratory distress (use of accessory muscles, chest indrawing, grunting, nasal

L88.content: - flaring), rhonchi, bronchial breathing, pleural rub

L89.content: abdominal tenderness, liver or spleen enlargement, masses, ascites loin/pelvic

L92.content: lymphangitis swollen tender joints bone tenderness, swelling bleeding, petechiae

L94.content: - • Underlying risk factors or comorbidity which may either increase severity of condition or

L95.content: - impact management- diabetes mellitus, sickle cell disease, malignancy, pregnancy, HIV,

L96.content: - alcoholic liver disease, prior antibiotic therapy ( may increase risk of MDR organisms)

L97.content: - • Appropriate initial investigations

L98.content: - • Appropriate empiric therapy awaiting results of clinical investigations

L99.content: - • Consider overlapping diagnoses

L101.content: - Defining the initial syndrome can be useful to narrow down the possible infectious agent.

L102.content: - • Fever – Malaria, leptospirosis, dengue, typhoid, scrub typhus, other rickettsial illness,

L103.content: - chikungunya, pyelonephritis

L104.content: - • Fever with thrombocytopenia/rash: dengue, malaria,leptospirosis,

L105.content: - • Fever with rash -dengue, measles, typhoid, rubella, HIV, viral illness, scrub typhus,

L106.content: - meningococcal infection

L107.content: - • Fever with respiratory symptoms- influenza, community acquired pneumonia,

L109.content: - • Fever with hepatorenal syndrome: falciparum malaria, leptospirosis, scrub typhus and

L110.content: - hepatitis E or A with fulminant hepatic failure. Modest elevation in leptospirosis and

L111.content: - malarial hepatitis. Higher in viral hepatitis.

L112.content: - • Fever with mental status change- meningitis, encephalitis ( HSV, Japanese B,

L113.content: - enterovirus) cerebral malaria, typhoid encephalopathy, scrub typhus

L115.content: - • Antipyretics to control fever- paracetamol in most cases. 500-1000mg PO q8h. Max

L117.content: - • Tepid sponging

L118.content: - • Assess hydration status. If able to take PO, allow for water, lime juice, kanji or ORS

L119.content: - solution, especially if diarrheal symptoms or vomiting.

L120.content: - • IV fluids if unable to take orally, ongoing dehydration due to vomiting or diarrhea

L121.content: - • with severe dehydration, ileus or shock or confusion. Normal saline for most patients.

L122.content: - • Oxygen if respiratory symptoms and low oxygen saturation. Assess for need for

L123.content: - higher level of care

L124.content: - • Mask for contacts if respiratory viral syndrome suspected

L126.content: - • Fever with URI symptoms of duration <3 days should be managed with supportive

L127.content: - care unless convincing signs of pneumonia exist or conditions like purulent tonsillitis

L128.content: - or otitis media are present.

L129.content: - leptospirosis. Leucopenia in Dengue, Thrombocytopenia in malaria and Dengue.

L130.content: - • Creatinine, liver function tests (SGPT, SGOT, bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase)

L131.content: - • POC glucose

L132.content: - • Urinalysis if urinary symptoms present. A reflex sample for urine culture should be

L133.content: - drawn by clean catch midstream sample.

L134.content: - • Malaria rapid antigen card test [ HRP- P falciparum (high Sn and Sp)/LD antigen

L135.content: - (lower Sn and high Sp)]. If available malarial smear. Negative RDT should be

L136.content: - followed by smear (or repeat RDT) if suspicion high. Malaria less likely if 2 neg

L137.content: - RDTs. Malarial RDTs may stay positive for >3-4 weeks in highly endemic areas.

L138.content: - • Dengue card test for NS1 Ag, IgM and IgG

L139.content: - • Influenza or COVID antigen test.

L141.content: - • If initial RDTs are negative, and fever >3 days, enteric fever, leptospirosis and scrub

L142.content: - typhus or other etiologies may need to be investigated.

L143.content: - • Elevated transaminases may suggest enteric fever or rickettsiosis vs other cause of AUFI

L145.content: - • Blood cultures should be a high priority to rule out typhoid/enteric fever or other

L146.content: - infections where severe presentation could be due to bacteremia. At least 20-30 ml of

L147.content: - blood should be collected and inoculated in aerobic bottles. Anaerobic cultures may be

L148.content: - drawn where resources exist.

L149.content: - • A chest X ray may reveal occult pneumonia and could be an ordered test if respiratory

L150.content: - symptoms are prominent

L151.content: - • IgM antibodies for leptospirosis and scrub typhus could be ordered. Sensitivity of such

L152.content: - tests is poor, especially earlier in illness. Microscopic agglutination test (MAT), the

L153.content: - reference standard for diagnosing leptospirosis but may not be available.

L154.content: - • IgM ELISA for scrub typhus may be available. The indirect fluorescent Ab (IFA) is a

L155.content: - mainstay but may not be available. Most common cutoff titer is 1:50

L157.content: - In non-malarial AUFI, when patient has moderate to serious severity of illness, empirical

L158.content: - treatment may be indicated while awaiting results of tests including blood cultures. Doxycycline

L159.content: - or azithromycin may be appropriate initial therapy for those who are not seriously ill and do not

L160.content: - need parenteral antimicrobial therapy. (PMID 24748368). Both the drugs have a comparable

L161.content: - efficacy against rickettsia organisms and Leptospira. Azithromycin may be a better option if

L162.content: - enteric fever suspected and may have lower incidence of adverse effects (PMID 17638600,

L163.content: - 22975540, 22718054). For those needing parenteral antimicrobial therapy a combination of

L164.content: - ceftriaxone and doxycycline may be appropriate.

L166.content: - • P vivax: Chloroquine X3 days [10mg/kg on day 1 (4 tabs) , 10mg/kg on day 2 (4 tabs)

L167.content: - and 5 mg /kg on day 3 (2 tabs)] + primaquine 0.25 mg/kg/d (6 tabs/d) X14 days*

L168.content: - • P falciparum:

L169.content: NE: Artemether-Lumefantrine [80mg/480mg (4 tabs) BID] X3 days and

L170.content: - primaquine 0.75 mg/kg on day 2

L171.content: Other states: Artesunate 200 mg X3 days + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (750

L172.content: - mg/37.5 mg X1 dose) plus primaquine 0.75 mg/kg on day 2

L173.content: - (* Primaquine is contraindicated in infants, pregnant women and individuals with G6PD

L175.content: Suggested Treatment Regimens for Enteric fever

L176.content: - Severe illness or inpatient care (confusion, prolonged fever, organ dysfunction)

L177.content: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (50-100 mg/kg/d) for 10-14 days*

L180.content: Azithromycin: 1g PO daily (10-20 mg/kg/d) for 7 days

L181.content: Cefixime 400 mg PO twice daily (20mg/kg in 2 divided doses) for 10-14 days#

L182.content: - Fluoroquinolones should not be used. TMP/SMX 960 mg BID may be considered if

L183.content: - susceptibility testing confirms no drug resistance.

L184.content: - (*antimicrobial susceptibility testing to rule out XDR S typhi)

L185.content: - (# may be used for de-escalation from initial IV therapy. May be associated with slower

L186.content: - defervescence and higher rate of on treatment failure)

L189.content: Doxycycline 100 mg BID (2 mg/kg/d in 2 doses) X 7 days

L190.content: Azithromycin 500 mg PO daily for 3 days or 10 mg/kg on day 1 f/b 5 mg/kg/d for

L193.content: Penicillin G (1.5 -3 million U IV q 6h), OR Ceftriaxone 1-2 g IV

L194.content: - daily/ Cefotaxime1 g IV every six hours*

L195.content: - (*Penicillin and cephalosporins lack activity against rickettsiae and so should be avoided when

L196.content: - rickettsial infection cannot be ruled out)

L198.content: - • Doxycycline 100 mg PO/IV BID (2 mg/kg/d in 2 doses) X 7 days

L199.content: - • Azithromycin 500 mg PO/IV daily for 3#L200

L201.content: - • Reassess for

L202.content: Not improving in the expected time frame

L203.content: Getting worse in spite of appropriate treatment

L204.content: New symptoms appear- e.g., rash, seizures, altered sensorium, jaundice, reduced

L205.content: - urine output, etc.

L206.content: - • Isolation of patient from other household contacts if possible

T1.title: Can broadly be malarial or non-malarial.

Higher 2 months after start of monsoon season
Paroxysmal fevers, chills, sweats. Hyperparasitemia with P falciparum can cause shock, renal failure, hemolysis

RDT
Malarial smear (sensitivity may be low and user dependent)
2nd line- malaria PCR
All over and more cases in south, west
Fever + headache, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia
rash. Platelets <150k. Symptoms last 2-7 days. 3-7 days after initial symptoms pt can develop dengue shock or hemorrhagic fever with purpura, bleeding and hypotension.

(Sn 75-93% and Sp 88-100%).
Detectable 1-9 days post fever, higher in primary infection.
IgM band cross reacts with Chikungunya.
2nd line Dengue PCR or IgM capture ELISA (MAC-ELISA)
Endemic but higher Jul-Oct, occasional food borne epidemic
Fever malaise. Diarrhea <50%. Splenomegaly. Secondary worsening in week 2. Could lead to encephalopathy and intestinal perforation
Blood cultures (pos 40-80%). Need higher volume of cultured blood
Urban slums after flooding. a/w rodent exposure. In rural areas work in paddy fields or having pets at home
Fever, malaise, headache. Conjunctival suffusion and myalgias prominent. Jaundice, hepatitis and renal failure, pulmonary hemorrhage (5-15%)

IgM ELISA
2nd line microscopic agglutination test >200
Sn of both tests low (<50%) in first week and may be improved when tested in week 2 (PMID10586903)
Northeast, east and south India. Majority rural, agricultural laborers
Fever, headache, myalgias, rash, lymph node swelling, confusion. May have eschar (22%) at site of mite bite which predates symptoms by around 7-10 days.

IgM ELISA
2nd line PCR or IFA
All over but max KA, MH, TL, UK
Fever, polyarthralgia, rash, headache, conjunctivitis, back pain, nausea, rash. 30-
Post monsoon season and second peak in Jan-Mar
Close contact history. Fever, cough, myalgia, sore throat, headache
Flu Ag, COVID Ag on nasal or nasopharyngeal swab
Other causes include focal infection with bacteremia e.g pyelonephritis or abdominal abscess or acute meningoencephalitis: Japanese B encephalitis, HSV encephalitis, Nipah virus disease

T2.title: Severity Assessment
content: Temperature – high grade fever, associated rigors
May be associated with bacteremia, abscesses, malaria, pyelonephritis or cholangitis.

Assess for dehydration esp in summer months.
Blood cultures have higher yield with rigors
HR -tachycardia out of proportion to fever (expect 10 beats increase per deg F rise, or 18 bts/deg C)
May be a sign of myocarditis.(COVID or viral illness)
RR- tachypnoea out of proportion to fever (Normal RR 16-24/min. Any RR above 30 /min- view with caution)
May be a sign of pneumonia or sepsis
Assess with pulse oximetry if available Chest X ray if available.
Low BP may be a sign of sepsis or shock/dehydration

Administration of intravenous fluids or rehydration. 30ml/kg over 30 minutes Repeat bolus if severe dehydration persists/pulses remain weak Then 70ml/kg over 2.5 hours Reassess after fluid administration
Hydration- assess tongue/oral mucosa, skin turgor, urine output by history
Can occur due to diarrheal illness, or from nausea/vomiting, low PO intake
Administration of intravenous fluids or rehydration with ORS if due to fluid losses. 2.2 – 4 litres of ORS over 4 hours
May be from sepsis, cerebral malaria, typhoid encephalopathy, scrub typhus, meningitis
Assess neck stiffness, need for lumbar puncture. Assess for ability to protect airway Assess for focal weakness, periodic breathing, directional gaze

pneumonia.description: This pathway outlines Adult Community Acquired Pneumonia management, covering assessment, diagnostics, risk stratification, empiric antibiotic therapy, and discharge planning, with adaptations for resource-limited settings and specific infections.

L3.content: - Existing guidelines from professional bodies, clinical resources, and intergovernmental

L4.content: - resources for the management of pneumonia in resource-limited settings

L10.content: - Indian Council of Medical Research antimicrobial guidelines

L16.content: If unstable, resuscitate +/- transfer to higher level of care

L20.content: - Routine chest radiography is not required for patients who have:

L21.content: A clinical presentation consistent with CAP AND

L26.content: NB: our preference is for all patients to have CXR if possible. However,

L127.content: - infrastructure limitations can prohibit this. In the case CXR is not available,

L128.content: - careful clinical diagnosis can be considered. In outpatient settings globally, CAP

L129.content: - is often diagnosed without CXR.

L30.content: - Chest XR should be obtained for patients who are:

L31.content: Unwell, clinically unstable, have evidence of severe disease, or hypoxic OR

L35.content: - All patients with suspected CAP should be screened for COVID-19

L36.content: - During flu season, consider screening patients with suspected CAP for influenza A/B

L37.content: - Patients suspected of tuberculosis should be investigated according to local

L40.content: - Decision to manage patient as an outpatient or inpatient to be determined through risk stratification and clinical judgment

L41.content: - CRB65, CURB65 and PSI can be used to stratify risk (Appendix 3)

L42.content: CRB65 is the simplest tool and does not require blood tests

L43.content: - Investigations such as arterial blood gas, full blood count, and biochemistry may aid in risk stratification (and are required by the PSI)

L44.content: IF patient suitable for outpatient management of CAP

L46.content: - Initiate empiric therapy for CAP with first line oral agent (Appendix 1)

L48.content: - Outpatient CAP should be treated for 5 days

L49.content: Ensure afebrile > 48 hours and clinically stable prior to stopping antibiotics

L50.content: IF patient requires inpatient management of CAP

L51.content: - Assess capacity to manage at CSA partner site

L53.content: - Use the ATS/IDSA Major and Minor criteria to determine regular ward vs ICU level care (Appendix 4)

L54.content: - Take sputum and blood cultures if possible (only in severe CAP, as defined in the appendix)

L55.content: - Start IV empiric antibiotic therapy as soon as possible (Appendix 1)

L56.content: If patient requires transfer, give first dose of antibiotics prior to transfer

L57.content: If intravenous access not possible at CSA site, then IM ceftriaxone can be considered as a temporising measure

L58.content: - Give antibiotics for at least 5 days

L59.content: - Initial empiric therapy can be de-escalated as patient clinically improves

L60.content: - If patient does not improve clinically on empiric therapy, re-assess patient and consider:

L65.content: - If within 3 days of symptom onset, start oseltamivir 75mg BD for 5 days

L66.content: - Cover with empirical antibiotics given the risk for bacterial superinfection/co-infection

L70.content: - Follow-up should be arranged with patient prior to discharge

L71.content: Arrange follow up in 48–72 hours to assess response and stability

L72.content: Arrange an additional follow up in 4–6 weeks to if patient requires

L73.content: - Covid/Influenza/Pneumococcal vaccine catch-up

L76.content: - The following tests do not need to be done routinely for suspected CAP suitable for outpatient management

L81.content: These tests can be considered if severe CAP requiring inpatient management, or if patient has co-morbidities

L82.content: - Do not treat CAP empirically with carbapenems (e.g. meropenem, imipenem)

L83.content: Carbapenems have an unnecessarily broad spectrum of coverage for CAP

L84.content: - Do not treat CAP empirically with anti-MRSA or anti-pseudomonal agents

L85.content: Most CAP is not caused by MRSA or pseudomonas – these organisms do not need to be routinely covered

L86.content: - Do not prescribe steroids for CAP

L87.content: Multiple trials have failed to show a clinical benefit from corticosteroid administration in CAP

L89.content: *Avoid respiratory fluroquinolones unless TB ruled out

L90.content: - If prior history of respiratory MRSA

L92.content: Obtain cultures/PCR to guide ongoing therapy

L93.content: Vancomycin/MRSA cover should be stopped if MRSA is not identified on laboratory testing

L94.content: - If prior history of respiratory pseudomonas aeruginosa

L95.content: Initiate treatment with antipseudomonal cover (piperacillin/tazobactam 4.5g every 6 hours or cefepime 2g three times daily)

L96.content: Obtain cultures/PCR to guide ongoing therapy

L97.content: Pseudomonal cover should be stopped if pseudomonas is not identified on laboratory testing

L98.content: - If MRSA or pseudomonas is suspected based on patient (e.g. underlying structural lung disease) or epidemiological factors

L99.content: In non-severe disease, obtain cultures/PCR but withhold MRSA/pseudomonas cover unless confirmed on laboratory testing

L100.content: In severe disease, add MRSA or pseudomonas coverage, obtain cultures/PCR to guide ongoing need for MRSA/pseudomonas coverage

L103.content: *Sputum sample should be sent for TB testing in patients commencing on respiratory fluroquinolones

L105.content: Characteristics of penicillin allergy should be clarified prior to initiation of treatment

L106.content: While up to 10% of patients report penicillin allergies, greater than 90% of these patients

L107.content: - do not have evidence of penicillin allergy on subsequent testing

L109.content: Appendix 4 – ATS/IDSA Major and Minor criteria for determining regular ward vs ICU disposition

L110.content: Validated definition includes either one major criterion or three or more minor criteria

L111.content: - If meeting this definition, patient should be managed in an intensive care setting

L113.content: - Septic shock with need for vasopressors

L125.content: *Due to infection alone (i.e. not chemotherapy related)

T1.title: Appendix 1: Empiric Treatment of Pneumonia
content:
Amoxicillin 1g three times daily OR
Doxycycline 100mg twice daily OR
Azithromycin 500mg first day then 250mg daily thereafter OR
Clarithromycin 500mg twice daily

Amoxicillin/Clavulanate 875/125 twice daily OR cefuroxime 500mg twice daily

AND

Doxycycline 100mg twice daily OR
Azithromycin 500mg first day then 250mg daily thereafter OR
Clarithromycin 500mg twice daily

T2.title: Appendix 2: Empiric treatment of CAP at CSA partner sites in patients with confirmed anaphylactic reaction to penicillins
content:
Doxycycline 100mg twice daily OR
Azithromycin 500mg first day then 250mg daily thereafter OR
Clarithromycin 500mg twice daily

Doxycycline 100mg twice daily OR
Azithromycin 500mg first day then 250mg daily thereafter OR
Clarithromycin 500mg twice daily

OR

Levofloxacin 750mg daily OR
Moxifloxacin 400mg daily*

T3.title: CURB-65
content: Systolic BP < 90 mmHg or Diastolic BP ≤ 60 mmHg
Short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
Severe pneumonia, inpatient management, consider ICU
Severe pneumonia, inpatient management, consider ICU

T5.title: CRB-65
content: Systolic BP < 90 mmHg or Diastolic BP ≤ 60 mmHg

T7.title: Appendix 5 – Checklist for discharge
content: Outpatient vs Inpatient vs Inpatient ICU

anaemia.description: This document outlines the Anaemia Pathway in India, highlighting the high prevalence of anaemia among women (57.2%) and men (25%) based on NFHS5 data. It details past and current national programs to combat anaemia, acknowledges the persistent challenge despite these efforts, and identifies drivers and barriers to improvement. The pathway further delves into the causes of anaemia, emphasizing iron deficiency, and provides a sequence for diagnosis and management, including criteria for different MCV levels and treatment protocols for IDA, B12/folate deficiency, and specific considerations for thalassemia, sickle cell, and malaria-related anaemia.

L3.content: - • Point prevalence of anaemia is high in India

L4.content: - • NFHS5 data:

L9.content: - • National Nutritional Anaemia Prevention Programme free iron and folic acid

L10.content: - supplementation for children, expectant/nursing mothers, women who attend family

L11.content: - planning services

L13.content: - • 2013 National Iron Plus Initiative free iron and folic acid for children/adolescents

L15.content: - • Other programs in the past

L18.content: National Programme for Nutritional Support to Primary Education (Mid-day Meal

L21.content: Rajiv Gandhi Scheme for Girls Empowerment of Adolescent, SABLA

L23.content: - • Currently Anemia Mukt Bharat

L24.content: - • Despite multiple national programs targeting anaemia, overall rates of anaemia have not

L25.content: - decreased (per serial NFHS’)

L27.content: - • Inadequate dietary intake (vegetarian diet)

L28.content: - • Loss of iron during menstrual cycle

L29.content: - • Repeated pregnancy/lactation

L32.content: - • Inadequate supplies/coverage of programs

L36.content: - • National Rural Health Mission Guidelines for Control of IDA

L37.content: - • Anemia Mukt Bharat Intensified National Iron Plus Initiative

L38.content: Causes of anaemia (with an emphasis on LMICs)

L39.content: - • Decreased production

L41.content: Other nutritional deficiencies (folic acid, B12, A)

L45.content: - • Loss of RBCs

L47.content: - • Increased destruction (haemolysis)

L51.content: Iron-deficiency anaemia (IDA) vs non-iron deficiency anaemia (NIDA)

L52.content: - • It is likely that the vast majority of anaemia in India is IDA

L53.content: - • In a 2007 study of 100 non-pregnant, non-lactating women in Bangalore, 95% of anaemic

L54.content: - women were iron deficient

L55.content: - • In a 2022 study of 258 mothers (pregnant or post-natal), 65.9% were anaemic. Of women

L56.content: - with anaemia, 61.8% had normal ferritin levels

L57.content: However, risk of confounding here – given the patient population should have

L58.content: - been commenced on iron supplementation at time of pregnancy

L59.content: - • The Comprehensive National Nutrition Survey (CNNS) provides more data, but only

L60.content: - sampled patients aged between 0-19

L61.content: In the survey, 12% of children aged 10-19 were anaemic and iron deficient and

L62.content: - 16.9% of the same group were anaemic but NOT iron deficient

L65.content: - • If there is active bleeding, achieve haemostasis. Refer for blood transfusion and further

L67.content: Consider anaemia patterns based on clinical presentation

L68.content: - • Diet/nutritional deficiency

L69.content: - • Acute blood loss

L70.content: - • Personal or family history of anaemia

L72.content: - • Menstrual history

L73.content: - • Alcohol intake

L74.content: - • Renal disease

L75.content: - • Underlying illness

L77.content: - • Helminth infection

L79.content: - • Sickle cell disease

L81.content: - • Hemo-cue (POC Hb)

L82.content: - • Is Hb < 8 (severe anaemia)?

L84.content: - • Is CBC available?

L85.content: If yes, perform CBC (Hb and MCV inform further assessment)

L86.content: If no, treat empirically for most likely cause based on age, demographics, local

L87.content: - epidemiology, clues from history

L89.content: - • MCV < 80 fL

L90.content: Common causes: iron deficiency, thalassemia, anaemia of chronic disease

L91.content: - • MCV 80-100 fL

L101.content: - • MCV > 100 fL

L109.content: - • Is ferritin testing or transferrin saturation available?

L110.content: If ferritin < 30 ng/mL, treat as iron deficiency

L111.content: If ferritin > 30 ng/mL, then check transferrin saturation

L112.content: - ▪ If TSAT < 20%, then treat as IDA

L113.content: - ▪ If TSAT > 20%, then IDA unlikely

L114.content: - • Consider anaemia of chronic disease or thalassemia

L115.content: - ▪ If MCV is low out of proportion to Hb, suspect thalassemia

L116.content: - • If ferritin/TSAT not available:

L117.content: Empirically treat for iron deficiency anaemia

L119.content: - • If IDA:

L121.content: - ▪ PO iron for mild anaemia, IV iron for moderate-severe anaemia

L122.content: - • Indian government offers combined iron-folic acid pills containing

L123.content: 100mg elemental iron and 500mcg of folic acid

L124.content: - ▪ Consider need for blood transfusion if life-threatening anaemia – this will

L125.content: require transfer to the closest district hospital

L126.content: - ▪ PO Albendazole 400mg once on an empty stomach

L127.content: Re-check Hb in 1 month for response

L128.content: - ▪ If Hb improved, continue iron replacement

L129.content: - ▪ 3-6 months of therapy are required for replenish iron stores

L130.content: - ▪ If not improved after 1 month: re-consider diagnosis (see pathway)

L132.content: - ▪ Parasites? (deworming), menstrual bleeding, peptic ulcer, GI malignancy,

L134.content: - • If thalassemia suspected

L135.content: Suspect if MCV out of proportion to the degree of anaemia

L136.content: Refer for electrophoresis and further management

L137.content: If patient has suspected thalassemia and is also iron deficient, iron deficiency

L138.content: should still be treated (with PO or IV iron)

L139.content: - • If sickle cell suspected

L140.content: Consider if severe anaemia or family history

L141.content: POC screening test for sickle cell (HemotypeSC is one POC test)

L143.content: - • Anaemia of chronic disease

L145.content: - • Send B12 and folate levels if available

L148.content: - • Give 1000mcg vitamin B12 IM once

L149.content: - • Then give 1000 mcg vitamin B12 PO daily

L151.content: - • Give 1-5g folic acid PO daily

L152.content: - • If B12 and folate normal, consider TSH, alcohol use, serum copper, peripheral blood

L153.content: - smear, liver function

L154.content: - • If no testing, treat empirically for B12 and folate deficiency

L156.content: - ▪ Give 1000mcg vitamin B12 IM once

L157.content: - ▪ Then give 1000 mcg vitamin B12 PO daily

L159.content: - ▪ Give 1-5g folic acid PO daily

L160.content: - • Re-check Hb and MCV in 1 month for response to treatment

L161.content: - • If no response Perform further assessment. May require additional diagnostic testing or

L164.content: - • Normocytic anaemia

L176.content: - • Is there access to iron studies/further testing?

L177.content: If no, consider concurrent iron/b12/folate therapy

L178.content: - • Perform iron studies (ferritin and transferrin saturation)

L181.content: - • If iron stores normal

L184.content: Consider therapy with B12 and folate

L185.content: Consider underlying illness/anaemia of chronic disease

L187.content: - • Is there local capacity to give IV iron infusion

L188.content: If no, then refer to district hospital/closest centre with capacity

L190.content: - ▪ IV iron sucrose (most common)

L191.content: - • Give 200mg in 100ml normal saline IV over 30 minutes daily until

L192.content: - desired dose is reached

L193.content: - o Use Ganzoni equation for iron deficiency anaemia

L194.content: - o Total iron deficit, mg = weight, kg x (target hemoglobin,

L195.content: - g/dL – actual hemoglobin, g/dL) x 2.4 + iron stores, mg

L196.content: - ▪ Iron Carboxymaltose (more expensive)

L197.content: - • 1gm in 100ml normal saline IV over 30 minutes

L199.content: - • See CSA malaria pathway (to be developed with the other fever content)

L200.content: - • Leads to anaemia through destruction of RBCs, and decreased RBC production

L201.content: - • Diagnose and treat as per National Malaria Guidelines

heart_failure.description: This Heart Failure Pathway addresses HFrEF and HFpEF management in India, focusing on diagnosis, guideline-directed medical therapy, and local adaptations for resource limitations and cost.

L3.content: - • Divided into heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and heart failure with

L4.content: - preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)

L5.content: - • HFrEF and HFpEF present with similar symptoms

L7.content: - • In India, burden of HF is high

L8.content: Estimate from 2010, 1.3-4.6 million

L10.content: - • 1 year mortality from HF in India is 23%

L11.content: - • IHD is the leading cause of mortality in India

L12.content: - • Burden not just directly from IHD, but the sequelae of cardiac ischemia, including heart

L15.content: - • This pathway should be considered in conjunction with (mostly to be written)

L23.content: - • How do we treat HF at CSA partner sites?

L24.content: - • What are the barriers to HF management in India?

L27.content: - • “The best adapted solution to the problem at hand”

L30.content: - • Clinical signs suggestive of HF

L31.content: - • ECG may show LV hypertrophy, evidence or previous ischaemia

L32.content: - • Echocardiogram with LVEF < 40% consistent with HFrEF

L33.content: This will likely require referral to nearest district hospital

L34.content: Echocardiogram ability of partner locations to be determined

L35.content: - • Pregnant patients require pregnancy specific management – this pathway cannot be used

L37.content: - • See appendix (NYHA Class)

L39.content: - • Ischaemic heart disease

L40.content: HF is common sequelae of coronary artery disease

L41.content: Risk reduction and symptomatic management as per CSA IHD pathway (TBD)

L47.content: - • Valvular disease

L54.content: - • furosemide 20-40mg once or twice a day

L55.content: Morning and midday dosing to avoid nocturnal diuresis

L56.content: Monitor renal function once a week

L57.content: Titrate to minimum dose required to eliminate evidence of fluid retention

L58.content: Can provide a weigh scale to facilitate this

L61.content: - • Drug from each of the below classes should be initiated at time of diagnosis

L62.content: Dosages and sequence of initiation in Appendix I

L63.content: See below if specific therapies unavailable at CSA partner site

L64.content: - • Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI), angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)

L65.content: - inhibitor, or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB)

L67.content: - ▪ Preference for ARNI if possible – however, significant barriers due to cost

L68.content: ACE inhibitor: Captopril, enalapril, lisinopril, ramipril

L69.content: - ▪ Lisinopril and ramipril and once daily dosing, which may be preferable

L71.content: - ▪ Candesartan, losartan, valsartan

L72.content: The use of ARNI/ACE/ARB in patients with eGFR < 30 is not contraindicated,

L73.content: - but caution should be exercised

L74.content: - • Beta blocker

L75.content: Evidence based beta-blockers: Bisoprolol, carvedilol, metoprolol XR

L76.content: - • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRA)

L78.content: Monitor serum potassium, down titrate or discontinue if serum potassium elevated

L80.content: - • SGLT2 inhibitor

L82.content: Contraindications: T1DM, symptomatic hypotension, frequent UTI, risk factors

L83.content: - for foot amputation, eGFR < 30 (dapagliflozin), eGFR < 20 (empagliflozin)

L84.content: - • Monitor blood pressure and electrolytes post initiation

L85.content: - • Ensure SBP > 100

L87.content: - • On the basis of current evidence, combination therapy with an ARNI, BB, MRA and

L88.content: - SGLT2 inhibitor has the greatest mortality benefit for patients with HFrEF, and is the

L89.content: - CSA preferred regimen

L90.content: - • However, some of these drugs may not be available at CSA partner sites, due to location

L91.content: - or cost

L92.content: - • If the above medications are not available, the below alternative regimens can be

L93.content: - considered (Appendix II)

L94.content: - • If ARNI unavailable

L95.content: Replace ARNI with ACEi (e.g. ramipril) or ARB (e.g. valsartan)

L96.content: - • If SGLT2 unavailable

L99.content: - • Digoxin is commonly used for the treatment of heart failure in India

L100.content: Robust evidence to support the use of digoxin in HFrEF is lacking

L101.content: Digoxin use does not appear to reduce mortality, but may reduce hospitalisations

L102.content: This should be balanced against the risks of digoxin therapy (i.e. digoxin

L103.content: - toxicity), and difficulty with monitoring drug levels in the rural Indian setting

L104.content: - • In general, we do not recommend the use of digoxin in heart failure, especially if any of

L105.content: - the above therapies are available

L106.content: - • If digoxin is to be used (not evidence based), starting dose:

L108.content: 0.125mg every second day or 0.0625mg daily if eGFR < 30, or elderly, or low

L109.content: - body weight

L110.content: Check electrolytes (particularly potassium) prior to initiation

L111.content: - • Exercise particular caution if digoxin used in conjunction with drugs that suppress heart

L112.content: - rate (e.g. beta blockers), or increase digoxin concentration (e.g. furosemide)

L113.content: - • Have a high index of suspicion for digoxin toxicity (e.g. vomiting/nausea, visual

L114.content: - disturbances, arrhythmias)

L116.content: - • Patients with recent myocardial infarction and HFrEF

L117.content: Major studies of HFrEF have excluded patients with recent myocardial infarction

L118.content: ACEI/ARB, beta blockers and MRAs have been shown to be beneficial in these

L120.content: ARNI is not superior to ACEI in the setting of recent myocardial infarction

L121.content: The impact of SGLT2 in the post-MI period still being studied

L122.content: - • Lifestyle modifications (see CSA risk factor/lifestyle modification pathway)

L123.content: - • Cardiac rehab

L124.content: Refer to physiotherapist/local cardiac rehab program

L125.content: Can give education materials for home cardiac rehab

L128.content: - • Smoking cessation

L129.content: Indications for referral to specialist cardiology services (adapted from Maddox et al, 2021)

L130.content: - • Heart failure refractory to therapy

L131.content: - • Persistent hypotension

L132.content: - • Renal failure

L133.content: - • Heart failure with atrial fibrillation

L134.content: - • 2+ issues of decompensation in previous 12 months

L135.content: - • Valvular or structural heart disease

L136.content: - • Inability to tolerate medical therapy for heart failure

L137.content: - • Diagnostic uncertainty

L138.content: - • Patients who are potential candidates for device-based therapies

L140.content: - • The diagnosis of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction requires an

L142.content: - • Unlike HFrEF, there are limited therapeutic options in HFpEF

L143.content: - • If HFpEF confirmed:

L145.content: - ▪ Hypertension, AF, CAD risk management, AD, hyperlipidaemia, obesity,

L146.content: - anaemia, diabetes, CKD, OSA

L147.content: - • If fluid overload, diuretics

L151.content: - ▪ Consider SGLT2 inhibitor as first line

L152.content: - • If HFpEF with elevated BNP

L154.content: - • Avoid the following drugs unless prescribed for other conditions such as hypertension:

L155.content: ARNI, ACEi, ARB, calcium channel blocker, digoxin

L156.content: None of the above classes of drugs have been shown to improve clinical outcomes

L157.content: - in HFpEF

L160.content: Sequence of Initiation and Starting and Target doses of Pharmacotherapies for HFrEF (adapted from Maddox et al, 2021)

L162.content: - • For all patients commencing pharmacotherapy, monitor:

L167.content: - • ARNI or ACEI/ARB AND

L168.content: If starting ARNI, ensure no history of angioedema

L169.content: Commence starting dose, then assess tolerability every 2 weeks. If dose is

L170.content: - tolerated, then double dose every 2 weeks until target dose

L171.content: Tolerability defined as SBP > 100, lack of symptomatic hypotension

L172.content: - • Beta Blocker AND

L173.content: Commence at starting dose, doubling every 2 weeks until target dose

L174.content: Only bisoprolol, carvedilol and metoprolol have demonstrated mortality benefits

L175.content: - in HFrEF – avoid other beta blockers

L177.content: - • Aldosterone antagonist AND

L178.content: Commence starting dose, then assess tolerability. Dose can be doubled every 2

L179.content: - weeks until target dose

L180.content: Check electrolytes/potassium and renal function 2-3 days post initiation, then 7

L181.content: - days after initiation, and then at least every 3 months thereafter

L182.content: - • SGLT2 inhibitor AND

L183.content: Commence at starting dose, no titration is required

L189.content: - • Based on recent clinical trials, and in accordance with most updated global guidelines

L190.content: - • Sacubitril/Valsartan AND beta blocker (e.g. bisoprolol) AND MRA (e.g. spironolactone

L191.content: - or eplerenone) AND SGLT2 inhibitor (dapagliflozin or empagliflozin)

L192.content: - • Approx annual cost of this regimen: ₹77k

L194.content: - • E.g. due to cost, then use:

L195.content: - • ACEI (e.g. ramipril) or ARB (e.g. valsartan) AND beta blocker (e.g. bisoprolol) AND

L196.content: - MRA (e.g. spironolactone) AND SGLT2 inhibitor (e.g. dapagliflozin)

L197.content: - • Approx annual cost: ₹10k

L198.content: If sacubitril/valsartan AND SGLT2 inhibitors unavailable

L199.content: - • E.g. due to cost, then use:

L200.content: - • ACEI (e.g. ramipril) or ARB (e.g. valsartan) AND beta blocker (e.g. bisoprolol) AND

L201.content: - MRA (e.g. spironolactone)

L202.content: - • There are no alternative agents for SGLT2 inhibitors

L203.content: - • Approx annual cost: ₹3k

L204.content: *Bisoprolol can be replaced with carvedilol or metoprolol XR

L205.content: **Ramipril can be replaced with alternate ACE inhibitor, valsartan can be replaced with

L212.content: Sacubitril-valsartan reduced risk of death and hospitalisation compared to

L227.content: Eplerenone reduced risk of death and hospitalisation compared to placebo

L229.content: - HFrEF (Vaduganathan 2020)

L230.content: Treatment with ARNI + MRA + SGLT2 inhibitor superior to conventional therapy

L231.content: - with ACEI/ARB and BB

L232.content: Estimate magnitude of benefit for comprehensive disease-modifying therapy:

L233.content: - between 2.7 additional years (for an 80-year-old) to 8.3 additional years (for a 55-

L234.content: - year-old) before cardiovascular death or first hospital admission for heart failure

T1.title: Starting and Target Doses of Pharmacotherapies for HFrEF
content: 25 mg twice daily for weight <85 kg and 50 mg twice daily for weight ≥85 kg

T3.title: NYHA Functional Classification
content: No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath).
Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath).
Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea.
Unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort increases.

chestpain.description: This comprehensive pathway adapts Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) care for resource-poor Indian settings, focusing on local context for diagnosis, management, referral, training, and medication access to improve outcomes.

L3.content: This document presents a comprehensive Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) pathway tailored for

L4.content: resource-poor settings in India. It addresses the unique challenges faced in these settings while

L5.content: leveraging existing infrastructure and government initiatives to improve ACS care outcomes.

L9.content: - • Rapid assessment of consciousness, breathing, and circulation

L10.content: - • Quick pain assessment using OPQRST method

L12.content: - • Emphasis on visual assessment due to potential lack of monitoring equipment

L13.content: - • Training for healthcare workers to perform quick manual BP measurements

L14.content: - • Use of locally relevant pain scales (e.g., visual analog scale with culturally appropriate images)

L17.content: - • 12-lead ECG performed and interpreted by trained personnel

L19.content: - • Alternatives for facilities without ECG machines:

L20.content: Use of smartphone-based ECG devices (e.g., AliveCor; https://alivecor.in)

L26.content: - • Oxygen therapy if needed (if patient has hypoxia; no significant benefit in the absence of it-

L27.content: - https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1706222#:~:text=Discussion,of%20rehospitaliza

L28.content: - tion%20with%20myocardial%20infarction.; Hofmann and in NEJM have shown the results of a

L29.content: - registry-based, randomized clinical trial of the use of supplemental oxygen in 6629 patients in

L30.content: - Sweden who had suspected acute myocardial infarction and did not have hypoxemia. Patients

L31.content: - were randomly assigned to supplemental oxygen administered through an open face mask (6

L32.content: - liters per minute for 6 to 12 hours) or to ambient air. The trial was adequately sized for the

L33.content: - assessment of hard clinical end points, with a primary end point of death from any cause at 1

L34.content: - year. Supplemental oxygen was not associated with lower all-cause mortality at 1 year than

L35.content: - ambient air, and the rate of a key secondary end point — rehospitalization for acute myocardial

L36.content: - infarction within 1 year — also did not differ significantly between the study groups. These

L37.content: - results clearly support the view that supplemental oxygen offers no benefit in patients with acute

L38.content: - myocardial infarction who have normal oxygen saturation.

L39.content: - • oxygen therapy in the absence of hypoxemia may even be harmful

L40.content: - • Pain management

L46.content: - •Costs ₹55-70 for 30 tablets, not in Jan Aushadhi

L53.content: - •Costs ₹1500-2000, might be free in government hospitals

L55.content: Add anticoagulation to aspirin and Plavix; transfer to a PCI center asap

L57.content: Dose: 60 units/kg IV bolus (max 4000 units) followed by 12 units/kg/hour infusion

L59.content: Typical market price: ₹150-200 per 5000 IU vial

L60.content: Note: Preferred in resource-poor settings due to lower cost and no need for refrigeration

L64.content: Typical market price: ₹250-350 per 40mg prefilled syringe

L65.content: Note: Consider this option only if cold chain can be maintained

L141.content: This comprehensive ACS pathway for resource-poor settings in India demonstrates a deep

L142.content: understanding of the unique challenges and opportunities within the Indian healthcare system.

L143.content: By adapting international best practices to the local context, leveraging existing government

L144.content: initiatives, and addressing specific resource constraints, this pathway aims to improve ACS care

L145.content: outcomes across diverse settings in India.

stroke.description: This pathway addresses stroke care in India, detailing initial workup, CT scan dependence, thrombolysis considerations, and management for ischemic, hemorrhagic, and TIA cases, with emphasis on resource limitations.

L3.content: - • 3rd leading cause of mortality in India

L4.content: - • Age adjusted prevalence: 84-262/100,000 in rural, 224-424/100,000 in urban areas

L5.content: Lower rate in rural – is this due to higher mortality? Or inadequate ascertainment?

L6.content: - • Higher mortality rate in rural compared to urban settings (28-day mortality 37.1% rural

L7.content: - vs 24.5% urban in one study)

L8.content: - • Timely CT scan/stroke response capacity does not exist in rural settings

L9.content: - • Very low rate of thrombolysis

L10.content: Approx 100 centers country-wide equipped for thrombolysis

L11.content: - • Indian National Stroke Guidelines contain reasonable recommendations, but the

L12.content: - resources required to implement these are lacking

L13.content: Global standard of care for stroke (high income settings)

L14.content: - • Time sensitive and resource dependent (that are difficult to implement in resource limited

L16.content: - • Initial/hyperacute management is guided by CT imaging (to differentiate between

L17.content: - ischaemic and haemorrhagic causes of stroke)  determines ongoing management

L18.content: Considerations for stroke care in India

L19.content: - • Healthcare system capacity

L21.content: - ▪ Hyperacute stroke management

L22.content: - ▪ Post-stroke inpatient care

L23.content: - ▪ Ongoing stroke rehabilitation

L24.content: - •Initial presentation may be delayed

L25.content: In a case series of 524 stroke patients from Jaipur, Rajasthan, the mean

L26.content: - presentation time was 26 hours post-symptom onset, and the mean distance

L27.content: - between place of residence and hospital was 66km

L28.content: Only 10.5% of patients presented within 4 hours

L29.content: Management of stroke of uncertain type (SOUT)

L30.content: - • Treatment paradigm for stroke depends on aetiology

L31.content: - • It is difficult to treat stroke without establishing cause

L32.content: - • Initiation of aspirin in first 48 hours after ischaemic acute stroke decreased risk of

L33.content: - recurrent ischaemic stroke and in-hospital death compared to placebo

L34.content: Subgroup analysis of the IST and CAST studies showed no outcome difference in

L35.content: - patients with haemorrhagic stroke who (inadvertently) received aspirin – but

L36.content: - study not designed to assess this

L37.content: - • Implications: it may be safe to give aspirin to SOUT, but this is unclear

L38.content: - • Given the benefit seen in IST/CAST was when aspirin was initiated in first 24 hours, and

L39.content: - highest risk of ICH expansion is in first 24 hours, giving aspirin between 25 and 48 hours

L40.content: - may be an option

L41.content: - • However, these recommendations are made by physicians in high income countries

L42.content: - • What is the magnitude of benefit?

L44.content: - • Is there a CT scanner at your facility

L46.content: If no, transfer to nearest centre with CT scanner

L59.content: - stroke”) then assume onset of symptoms was when the patient was last

L62.content: - symptoms and if there is capability to deliver tissue plasminogen activator

Diarrhoea.description: This pathway addresses adult diarrhea in India, defining it and highlighting its high mortality burden. It discusses local challenges like antibiotic misuse and delves into causes, severity assessment, rehydration, and antimicrobial treatment, emphasizing appropriate testing and tailored regimens.

L3.content: - • Passage of loose/watery stools 3+ times in 24 hours

L5.content: - • Diarrhoeal diseases 4th leading cause of deaths in India overall, number 1 infectious cause

L6.content: - of mortality (IHME)

L7.content: - • 632,000 diarrhea deaths (all ages) in 2019

L8.content: - • Greatest burden of diarrhoea deaths in the 70+ age group (385,000)

L10.content: - • Antibiotics are widely used for acute diarrhoea in India amongst both adults and children

L11.content: However, the majority of acute diarrhoeal syndromes do not require treatment

L12.content: - with antibiotics

L13.content: - • Diarrhoea in adults is not as well studied as in children

L15.content: - • Diarrhoea can be caused by viruses, bacteria, and protozoa

L16.content: - • Diarrhoea caused by viruses cannot be treated with antibiotics, and bacterial and

L17.content: - • protozoal diarrhoea often resolves without antibiotic therapy

L18.content: - • CSA performed a systematic review to provide further guidance in this area

L19.content: Search conducted to identify all Indian studies published in the last 5 years

L20.content: - reporting microbiological information on the aetiology of infectious diarrhoea.

L21.content: - Studies had to recruit from the general population, and test for multiple

L22.content: - pathogens, to reduce risk of bias

L23.content: 10 studies were identified from 9 states of India

L24.content: 4 studies included adults, 6 studies were limited to children only

L25.content: The yield of pathogen detection in included studies ranged from 16.3 (examining

L26.content: - parasites only) to 65.2%

L27.content: When studies investigating parasites only excluded, yield of microbiological

L28.content: - testing ranged from 25.6% to 65.2%

L29.content: Common pathogens included viruses (rotavirus, norovirus) and bacteria (E coli,

L30.content: - shigella, cholera)

L32.content: - • Patients in many parts of India do not need to see a doctor to obtain antibiotics for

L33.content: - diarrhoea  lack of stewardship

L34.content: - • Patients may not present to CSA partner sites with mild-moderate diarrhoea (can present

diabetic_foot_ulcer.description: This pathway addresses Diabetic Foot Ulcers, covering their global burden, screening methods, physical examination findings (WIfI classification), and management principles including debridement, off-loading, wound dressings, and treatment for infection and peripheral arterial disease.

L2.content: Approximately 18.6 million people worldwide are affected by a diabetic foot ulcer each year.

L3.content: These ulcers precede 80% of lower extremity amputations among people diagnosed with

L4.content: diabetes and are associated with an increased risk of death. Approximately 50% of ulcers become

L5.content: infected, with up to 20% of these requiring hospitalization; between 15% and 20% of moderate

L6.content: to severe infections eventually lead to a lower-extremity amputation. People with a diabetic foot

L7.content: ulcer have a 5-year mortality rate of 30%, with a mortality rate greater than 70% for people with

L9.content: According to the International Diabetes Federation, India had an estimated 77 million adults

L10.content: living with diabetes in 2019, and this number is expected to rise to 101 million by 2030. Up to

L11.content: approximately 34% of people with type 1 or 2 diabetes develop a foot ulcer during their lifetime.

L12.content: This incidence is similar when reviewing the limited published data from India.

L15.content: Individuals with diabetes are assessed for loss of protective sensation as a sign of large fiber

L17.content: - 1. The Semmes-Weinstein 5.07 monofilament test to assess for absence of pressure

L18.content: - sensation at a minimum of 3 sites per foot (likelihood ratio for ulceration range, 11-16)

L20.content: - 2. the 128-Hz tuning fork to assess for absence of vibratory perception (using an on-off

L21.content: - technique or timed methods; likelihood ratio range, 16-35) are important components of

L23.content: - 3. In the absence of this equipment, the Ipswich Touch Test is an acceptable alternative that

L24.content: - can be used to evaluate whether a patient can perceive light touch from an examiner’s

L25.content: - index finger applied to 6 or 8 prespecified sites on the feet (likelihood ratio range, 10-15)

L26.content: Physical exam in patients with DFU

L28.content: Physical examination should include evaluation for calluses, interdigital maceration, and

L29.content: thickened nails, which may indicate a fungal infection and may be associated with increased

L31.content: Digital deformities such as hammer toes or claw toes appear as increased prominence of the

L32.content: interphalangeal joints dorsally and the metatarsal heads on the plantar surface and are common

L33.content: sites of ulceration. The tip of a toe exposed to increased pressure in contact with the ground or

L34.content: shoe is also a common site of ulceration. Assessment of dorsiflexion and plantarflexion ankle

L35.content: range of motion can identify equinus deformity (ie, less than 0 degrees of dorsiflexion at the

L36.content: ankle joint), which increases forefoot plantar pressure. In a prospective study of 1666 people

L37.content: with diabetes, equinus deformity was present in 10.3% . Charcot arthropathy, defined as a foot

L38.content: fracture with possible joint dislocation in people with peripheral neuropathy, affects

L39.content: approximately 0.3% of people with diabetes, can lead to significant deformity, and increases the

L40.content: risk of a diabetic foot ulcer, particularly in the midfoot and ankle/hindfoot. Although

L41.content: approximately 40% of people with Charcot arthropathy have concomitant tissue loss, a unilateral

L42.content: red, hot, swollen foot without a wound or diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis may indicate

L44.content: Pulse palpation at the ankle and on the foot is a central part of the vascular examination, but

L45.content: palpable pulses have low sensitivity (71.7%) and specificity (72.3%) for detecting peripheral

L46.content: artery disease. Because peripheral artery disease affects approximately half of people with

L47.content: diabetic foot ulcers, clinicians should consider noninvasive testing with the ankle-brachial index.

L49.content: The Wound, Ischemia, Foot Infection (WIfI) classification system was developed and validated

L50.content: as a method to combine all 3 variables (wound, ischemia, and foot infection) and to accurately

L51.content: assess the risk of limb loss for patients with diabetic foot ulcers.

L52.content: Wound: Degree of tissue loss, class 1- small/shallow; class 2 exposed bone/joint/tendon; class 3

L53.content: extensive deep wound may/may not involve the calcaneum

L54.content: Infection: The diagnosis of diabetic foot infection is primarily based on clinical assessment and

L55.content: is suggested by presence of more than 2 signs of inflammation, such as erythema, swelling and

L57.content: DO NOT OBTAIN WOUND CULTURES: Randomized clinical trial data are not available to

L58.content: support obtaining wound cultures from all patients with diabetic foot ulcers

L59.content: An erythrocyte sedimentation rate greater than 70 mm/h can be helpful in improving diagnostic

L60.content: accuracy for osteomyelitis (likelihood ratio, 11)

L61.content: Particularly among hospitalized patients, for whom the pretest probability of osteomyelitis is

L62.content: high, the combination of a positive probe-to-bone test and plain film radiography can be

L63.content: sufficient to diagnose osteomyelitis (likelihood ratio, 14) without the need for other, more

L64.content: expensive radiological studies

L65.content: Ischemia: 1. Palpation of anterior tibial and posterior tibial pulses (35% sensitive, 100% specific-

L66.content: for wound healing)

L67.content: 2. Lower extremity peripheral artery disease can be assessed noninvasively with the ankle-

L68.content: brachial index. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) less than 0.90 is approximately 98% specific and

L69.content: approximately 85% sensitive for peripheral artery disease. Limitations of ABI- people with

L70.content: diabetes often have medial calcinosis of lower extremity peripheral vessels, resulting in falsely

L71.content: elevated peripheral pressures and a high ankle-brachial index that is insensitive to presence of

L72.content: peripheral artery disease. (RESOURCE LIMITATIONS) In these individuals, the toe-brachial

L73.content: index can be measured, since the digital arteries are less commonly affected by medial

L74.content: calcinosis.35 A toe-brachial index less than 0.70 is consistent with peripheral artery disease.33

L75.content: Toe pressure of 30 mm Hg or greater, transcutaneous oxygen pressure of 25 mm Hg or greater,

L76.content: and skin perfusion pressure of 40 mm Hg or greater have been associated with higher rates of

L77.content: ulcer healing. The sensitivity and specificity of transcutaneous oxygen pressure for ulcer healing

L78.content: were 0.72 (95% CI, 0.61-0.81) and 0.86 (95% CI, 0.68-0.95), respectively, with a diagnostic OR

L79.content: of 15.81 (95% CI, 3.36-74.45). This is compared with a relatively low prognoaccuracy for ulcer

L80.content: healing using the ankle-brachial index (with cutoffs of <0.9 and ≥1.3), with a sensitivity of 0.48

L81.content: (95% CI, 0.36-0.61), a specificity of 0.52 (95% CI, 0.42-0.63), and a diagnostic OR of 1.02 (95%

L83.content: A higher score on the WIfI scale is associated with lower extremity amputation and morbidity

L84.content: and can be used to determine the need for revascularization. WIfI scores of 1, 2, 3, and 4 were

L85.content: associated with 1-year amputation rates of 0%, 8%, 11%, and 38%, respectively

L91.content: Debridement: Debridement is a standardized approach used to facilitate healing.52 Healing is

L92.content: achieved by eliminating nonviable wound bed and wound edge tissue, including excess callus on

L93.content: the periphery and nonviable dermal tissue, as well as foreign materials and bacterial components.

L94.content: Although guidelines recommend regular debridement, defined as weekly or every other week,

L96.content: Off loading: The most effective treatment for off-loading a plantar foot ulcer is a knee-high

L97.content: nonremovable off-loading device, either a total contact cast or a knee-high walker rendered

L98.content: nonremovable. Two national surveys of clinicians in the United States and Australia show that

L99.content: the total contact cast was used in only 2% and 15% of patients, respectively, as a primary means

L100.content: of off-loading. Clinicians frequently cited patient preference as a reason for lack of total contact

L102.content: Dressings: Few data are available regarding the optimal wound dressing for diabetic foot

L103.content: ulcers.The selection of a wound dressing for a diabetic foot ulcer should be based on wound

L104.content: characteristics, ie, location, presence and/or degree of inflammation, and amount of exudate The

L105.content: dressing should promote a moist environment conducive to tissue growth and epithelial

L106.content: migration without causing excess maceration. It is important to select dressings that remove

L107.content: excess fluid to prevent further tissue inflammation and damage from prolonged contact with the

L108.content: wound or its periphery. In general, hydrogels are preferred for wounds that produce little

L109.content: exudative drainage, while alginates or hydrofibers are recommended for heavily draining wounds

L111.content: Osteomyelitis present- links to AvoMD abx pathways

L112.content: Osteomyelitis absent- links to AvoMD abx pathways

L113.content: Although many diabetic foot ulcer infections are superficial, some may require surgical

L114.content: intervention to remove infection in deep soft tissue. In the absence of an acute soft tissue

L115.content: infection in forefoot osteomyelitis, antibiotics may be as effective as surgery.

L118.content: In patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia who require revascularization for tissue

L119.content: healing, delayed revascularization is associated with slower healing. A prospective study of 478

L120.content: patients identified an improved rate of wound healing among patients undergoing

L121.content: revascularization with shorter time to healing among those who received a referral for

L122.content: revascularization within 56 days compared with those who had a longer time to revascularization

L123.content: (hazard ratio [HR], 1.96; 95% CI, 1.52-2.52; P < .001 [absolute rates not provided]).

L124.content: Revascularization should be offered to most patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia;

L125.content: however, cost, older age, presence and severity of medical comorbidities, impaired functional

L126.content: status, and shorter life expectancy are important preoperative factors to consider when

L127.content: determining whether revascularization is likely to improve outcomes.

T1.title: Off-loading methods
content: Total contact cast or knee-high walker rendered nonremovable

Reduces pressure at the ulcer by 80%-90% compared with a standard shoe[55]; promotes better healing compared with removable devices (relative risk, 1.24; 95% CI, 1.09–1.41 [absolute rates not provided]). First-choice off-loading treatment in international guidelines.[51]
Off-loading devices that can be removed by the patient

Reduces pressure effectively but does not promote healing as well as nonremovable walkers or total contact cast. Second-choice off-loading treatment in international guidelines.[51] A study of 20 patients wearing waist-mounted activity monitor and device-mounted monitor reported patients engaged in only 28% of their total daily activity while wearing the protective boot compared with when it was not worn (345 [SD, 219] min vs 874 [SD, 828] min; *P* = .01).[59]

T2.title: Dressing type
content: These dressings form a damp gel on absorption, necessitating a secondary dressing. They are conformable, filling dead spaces and managing moderate to heavy exudate effectively. Suitable for wounds with light to moderate serous drainage.

These dressings contain substances such as silver or iodine that inhibit bacterial growth in the wound, making them suitable for infected wounds or those at high risk of infection. However, it is important to note that, as with each of these categories, there is a lack of strong evidence recommending their use.

Derived from bovine, equine, porcine, or ovine (sheep) sources, these products help stimulate wound healing. Available in various forms such as gel, pad, paste, powder, and sheets. Some dissolve entirely while others need removal per the manufacturer’s guidelines. Ideal for wounds showing granulation tissue.
Thin, transparent dressings that foster a moist environment, promoting healing and enabling wound assessment without removal. Ideal for superficial wounds with minimal exudate.
These dressings are capable of absorbing moderate quantities of exudate and can be used under compression.

Highly permeable dressing material, suitable for wound cleaning, as a cover dressing, and for securing dressings. Gauze is not generally recommended as a primary wound dressing because it can remove healthy granulation tissue during dressing changes.
These bacteria-proof dressings facilitate autolytic debridement. They are not appropriate for infected wounds as they may damage fragile skin. Ideal for wounds with insignificant serous drainage.

These are glycerin and water-based products available as amorphous gels, sheets, or impregnated dressings. They can be antimicrobial, donate moisture to wounds, assist in autolytic debridement, and possibly reduce pain. They require a secondary dressing and are suitable for low-exudate wounds needing moisture.
